NewsLine.NewsLineText: SPORT-RALLYING-PEUGEOT:Rallying-2002 season will be hard to beat says Peugeot boss

body.p: SAN REMO, Italy, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Peugeot team boss Corrado Provera believes the team may struggle to repeat this season's exploits after they moved a step closer becoming double world champions.
Victory for Frenchman Gilles Panizzi and second place for Finn Marcus Gronholm in San Remo moved the French team to within four points of a third successive manufacturers' title.

Gronholm's six points for second increased his lead in the drivers' standings to 23 points and he needs to score just eight points from the remaining three rounds to land a second world title to add to his 2000 success.
The Finn heads team mate Briton Richard Burns in the standings with Panizzi fourth behind Ford's Colin McRae. Finn Harri Rovanpera, Peugeot's fourth driver, is seventh in the drivers' points chart.

"We have exceptional drivers and we will keep doing as we have done," Provera said. "If you look to the current drivers' classifications we are giving all of our drivers the chance to go for the title.
"It is true that the manufacturers' and drivers' championships are not decided mathematically but we would be crazy to lose them from this position.
"But we are not unbeatable, as Petter (Solberg) showed, and we will be working hard for the rest of the season and next year.
"I must say it will be difficult for us to be in better condition next year than are we are now."

Norwegian Solberg was the only non-Peugeot driver to set best stage times on the Italian asphalt roads and the Subaru driver denied Peugeot a clean sweep of the podium positions by holding off Burns for third place.

But Peugeot dominated the event with 15 fastest stage times between Panizzi, Gronholm and Burns and five of the top-ten finishers competing in 206 WRC's with Rovanpera ending ninth and French privateer Cedric Robert seventh.
When asked how many of the team's drivers could challenge for the title next year, Provera joked: "At least two, maybe three and possibly four."
Gronholm should wrap up proceedings this year in the remaining three rounds when the series moves on to his more favoured gravel-based events.
Victory in New Zealand in two weeks time could hand him the title before he heads to Australia and Great Britain, which hosts the final round of the season.
Gronholm knows he is on the verge of landing a second world crown and said he will approach the final rounds of the championship in a more relaxed manner.
"Of course it is good to have finished ahead of Richard all weekend and I now have a bigger lead," Gronholm said. "I'm more relaxed than I have been and I have a good feeling going into New Zealand."
His co-driver Timo Rautianen said he expects the title race to be resolved in the penultimate round in Australia, which starts on October 31 in Perth.
Rautianen said: "It is quite difficult to say, but we know it is possible in New Zealand if we are in front of Richard and Colin. But I think it will happen in Australia."
